results.notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection № MF54414.
Two collections of the same species from the same walk made by Bob Burns and Margaret Horman in deciduous woodlands, and combined together by me.
Naturally, these are porcini relatives, i.e. Boletus s.s./Boletus sect. Boletus. Overall, the gestalt is quite similar to that of B. nobilissimus, but the cap color (yellow-tan) of these immature fruiting bodies was lighter than shown in photos of John Plischke online and in Bessettes’ BENA. The coarsely reticulated whitish stipes bruised brownish in the lower 2/3. This is my first hands-on experience with nobilissimus. Half of the collection was left on the display and the other half was preserved.

results.notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection № MF54415.
Two immature fruiting bodies collected by Karen Fisher.
Perfumed odor was detected.
One half of the larger fruiting body was preserved for MycoFlora.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 6-May-21):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 738 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this collection by MycoFlora/FunDiS and posted to this observation (GenBank accession #MW882078). The ITS spacer in this taxon is 689 nucleotides long (ITS1 = 243 bps, 5.8S = 161 bps, ITS2 = 285 bps). It’s preceded by the last 33 characters of nrSSU and followed by the first 16 bps of nrLSU. The sequence is a “joined contig” because of a single point of heterogeneity late in ITS2 sublocus — the long forward read is joined at character #603 (counting from the start of ITS) with the short reverse read. There are no ambiguous positions present anywhere in the sequence.
> There are 3 matching ITS accessions with 98.5-99.7% similarity in GenBank: KY826139 (lowest similarity due to 8 ambiguities), KY826161 and KY654725. The first two are associated with vouchers from Canada and the third – from Florida. The Canadian accession are labeled as ‘Boletales sp.’, while the Floridian is misidentified as ‘Rubinoboletus sp.’. Hence, MW882078 is the first correctly identified ITS record for R. rhodosanguineus. All other published accessions of R. rhodosanguineus (11) involve other loci: LSU, APT6, COX-3, TEF-1 and RPB-2.

results.notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection № MF54416.
A single large and mature fruiting body growing in soil in deciduous woodlands collected by Sue van Hook at Walk #9. Half of this specimen was preserved for MycoFlora (NAMP).
This collection has already been posted to MO by Dave W as obs 326375.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 9-May-21):
> This collection was sequenced by MycoFlora/FunDiS. The ITS region in this organism is a bit of a mess. A full-length ITS sequence cannot be derived from the available forward and reverse reads because of two ostensibly well-spaced points of heterogeneity in the ITS2 region.
The forward read delivers the first 352 characters of the ITS spacer (full-length ITS1 and 5.8S subloci, 170 and 161 base pairs (bps), respectively, and the first 21 bps of ITS2) before becoming heteromorphic. In this case the heterogeneity is hopeless, as I couldn’t find a well-defined pattern within the two overlapping sets of peaks. The reverse read delivers the last 174 bps of the ITS2 sublocus before becoming heteromorphic and undecipherable. The sequence from the forward read was published in GenBank (MW882079) and uploaded to this post.
> A BLASTn-100 search of the forward read returned 6 nrDNA accessions labeled as ‘Leccinum/Leccinellum albellum’ as the top hits (98.8-99.2% similarity and 91-100% query cover). Following these, the % identity instantly drops to <92%. Examination of the GenBank accessions revealed that half of them are only 322-364 characters long – i.e., lacking >90% or all of the ITS2 region – while the rest are 588-697 nucleotides long. The longest published nrITS sequence of L. albellum, MH488723, is 691 bps long and features full-length ITS1-5.8S regions and an almost complete ITS2 sublocus.1
> Surprisingly, the ITS2 fragment of the MycoFlora sequence doesn’t match at all the ITS2 region in MH488723. Moreover, a general BLASTn search of this sequence fragment resulted in no hits due to “no significant similarity found”!!! This makes little sense. One possible scenario is that the reverse read didn’t come from the present collection. The other scenario implies that the two sequences don’t share a common overlap, meaning that the ITS2 region in L. albellum must be >500 long; this is exceptional in Basidiomycota and likely unprecedented for Boletaceae.2 This mystery aside, due to the length of the legible part of the reverse read being shorter than the cutoff for publication (200 bps), the ITS2 sequence was not submitted to GenBank.
> I have little doubt this collection is correctly identified as Leccinum albellum, based on my experience with this taxon as a morphologically variable species and support from LSU sequences derived from 4 distinct-looking voucher in my personal herbarium (none sampled for ITS). In light of the above discussion, it would be desirable to have a full-length nrITS sequence L. albellum in a public database.
References:
1 While I couldn’t find the starting motif of nrLSU (TTGACCTCAAATCA in Boletaceae) in MH488723, the considerable length of the ITS2 fragment (361 bps) suggests >80% coverage.
2 https://journals.plos.org/...

results.notes:
This is what I have learned to call the oak version of Neoboletus (or Sutorious if you will) subvelutipes. I posted this yesterday on the Facebook Boletes page and it’s caused enough uproar to cross-post here.
-
I find this species everywhere and know it very well. They start with red-with-yellow stems, yellow caps, and a yellow pore layer (more on the pores later). They soon age to have less red and more yellow in the stems, with fully red caps, and red pores with a yellow ring at the edge. Soon that edge turns red too, leaving the “beauty shot” specimen seen in the field guides. In old age the pores expand, diluting the pore color to an orange shade.
-
The array photos (Figures 1, 1.a, 1.b and 1.c) show both a yellow-pored baby and a red-pored youth, with their respective stipes lying next to them (and blue bullseye marks showing where the stipe was removed).
-
Knowledgeable people suggested that the “yellow pores” are actually a yellow membrane that covers the area as the tubes begin to grow. To answer this I went back to the same spot this morning and took some more photos showing the mushrooms growing right next to each other (Figure 2). Happily there was even an actual conjoined pair to eliminate any chance it was two different species growing together. I dismembered and photographed that pair (Figure 2.a) and sure enough, the baby has a yellow pore layer and the not-quite-a-baby is on its way to being red. I certify that the orange pores would have been crimson in a few hours, or at least by tomorrow. I don’t have that timing pegged down but I see this species hundreds of times every summer and have personally watched them progress like that.
-
But getting back to the question… am I looking at a yellow membrane on these babies or are the pores themselves yellow? [A NOTE TO BE EXTRA CLEAR: The only “membrane” I’ve ever heard of are the things that become (or don’t) a ring on the stem of Suillus, Amanitas, etc. Please educate me if there is another type of membrane to consider!]
-
To answer this I just (a day later) cut up those separated yellow- and red-pored caps that are the array. Closeup photos were taken with my snazzy new macro lens. They do not solve the question imho.
-
My assumption – which I would prefer to dignify as a “hypothesis” – was that the proto-tubes in specimens this young had their normal yellow but hadn’t been exposed to enough oxygen to turn red. My guess would have been that leaving them out overnight would do it. That was clearly wrong. Either these tubes are missing the chemicals that oxidize red, or they are covered by something that prevents the oxygen from getting in (the hypothetical membrane). In any case, the yellow pore layer was still yellow except for a small area where it was traumatized by removing the stipe (Figure 3). The profile shows that there are literally no tubes to speak of yet. (Figure 3.a)
-
The red-pored specimen (Figure 4 and 4.a) got darker overnight and shows actual tubes, but its pore layer really isn’t a whole lot more dimpled than the yellow pore layer! Both specimens show the “dimpling” that will become pores, but neither has what you could call an “open” hole.
-
Does this differ from what’s seen on “normal” baby boletes? My experience fails at this point All I know is that the pores on a typical baby bolete are invisibly small to the eye and slowly get bigger as the mushroom matures and the tubes lengthen. This is consistent with that – but if there is a “membrane” I could easily be missing it.
-
As expected, the flesh always blues quickly and profoundly. The flesh and tubes are yellow where they aren’t bruised blue. The mycelium is pale yellow. No chemical tests were performed, but I did not refrigerate anything and can do them today if people think that would still be useful.
-
I have never personally seen the red or yellow “hairs” in Peck’s original description of the base. We do see major red blotches in the flesh of the base when environmental factors or bugs have a say.
-
DIGRESSION FOR A SECOND DEBATE: Please focus in on the non-bruised yellow area in the base of the severed array specimen (Figure 1 and 1.a). That is the exact area that often turns blood red in older specimens! I have hypothesized that the enzymes to cause blue bruising are somehow missing in that bottom part of the base, and turn red when age or environmental conditions expose that spot to oxygen. Thoughts?
-
A FINAL QUESTION: Igor has done the testing to prove that these “oak subvelutipes” are a genetically distinct lookalike of the “hemlock subvelutipes” also found across the Northeast. So… What name go on this species 20 years ago in the pre-DNA days? Would these have been “discolor” or “luridiformis” rather than “subvelutipes?” [FN] Those old, morphology-only boletologists weren’t exactly dumb! There had to be a reason they agreed there were so many different species. How well do the differences they observed match up to the ones in this observation?
-
[FN] NO DEBATE ON NOMENCLATURE! We all know that discolor and luridiformis are (now mostly merged) European names that would have to be changed in any event. The point is that people with huge amounts of expertise had agreed there were separate species of red-mouth boletes based on morphological differences, and assigned those names to distinguish one type of morphology from the others. I only mean to ask if the dividing lines I am addressing match up to those older dividing lines.

results.notes:
Resembles bicolor but stipe is punctate rather than streaked with reddish tones.

Mixed oak, birch, hemlock, red maple forest. Cap reddish brown with purple tones, 5-11 cm. Pores yellow, slowly bruise bluish gray then gradually fade to pale brown. Stipe yellow ground color, covered with dark purplish red punctae at base, gradually thinning out toward the yellow apex, bruises blue. 7-11 cm long x 1-2 cm thick, curved toward the base. Slight whitish stem reticulation at the apex only. Cap flesh pale yellow, bruised red at insect holes, slowly turned bluish in spots. Stem flesh a darker yellow, otherwise bruising as the cap. KOH pale orange on flesh, amber/orange on cap. Ammonia pale blue on cap flesh, negative on stem flesh, dark yellowish green on cap. Iron salts blue-gray on flesh, greenish on cap. Spores subfusiform, smooth, 9-11 × 3.5-4.

results.notes:
This mushroom was found growing on a lawn by a member of the local mushroom club. The gestalt suggests Lepidella to me (although the cap margin appears to lack appendiculate material, and there are grooves along the margin). Habitat suggests this may be one of the saprobic Lepidellas. The collector reports an odor not unlike Roquefort cheese.

I realize this is a longshot. But, given that the occurrence of a saprobic Lepidella here in NE PA would likely be of interest, I think it’s best to post the observation and see what happens. Gills look way too pale for an Agaricus, and mushroom seems too robust for Lepiota (or any of the Lepiota allies).

results.notes:
A single fruiting body growing in an open area near a paved trail.
From a distance it gave a strong impression of A. virosa, owing to the white color, but once I saw the striations and dug up the upper part of the volva, the true sectional identity became clear. The volva was very friable and wound up in loose pieces upon excavation.
The only trees nearby were Scots Pine (P. sylvestris). There were a couple of small birch trees, too, but they were too far away to be the host.
I visited the mushroom the next day, but it didn’t develop any further, and there were signs it was actually drying up. I came back the following day (Aug. 8), and it was gone — I couldn’t find even a trace of it.

results.notes:
Microscopic analysis:

T. hirsutum confirmed through numerous long sharp setae and 15 septate spores.

H. papulasporae var. americanus spores: 9-18 × 2-4 µm, fusiform to cylindrical, hyaline.
results.location_name: Middle Creek Wildlife Management Area, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
A group of several fruiting bodies growing in association with European birch (B. pendula and/or B. pubescens) trees, with maple and linden nearby; after checking carefully, I couldn’t find other trees at this spot that could act as the mycorrhizal host for these boletes, so I am pretty sure it had to be the birch.
Caps up to 6-7 cm wide, darker brown, velvety and devoid of cracks when young, turning lighter brown to tan in age and developing cracks from the margin toward the center, with the disk being the less-cracked area; the flesh in cracks yellow to rarely pinkish. The pores are yellow when young, maturing dingy brownish-yellow, bluing when injured. The stipe is more or less equal, with a bright yellow narrow apex, deep red below and turning more yellow again toward the base, prominently longitudinally striate and a bit scruffy, but apparently not pruinose. The basal mycelium is pale yellow. Since I didn’t section these, the details of the context are not known.

results.notes:
NORTH AMERICAN MYCOFLORA PROJECT# 08108

ALSO FOUND AT: iNat #: https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/15707777

COMMON NAME is "Chanterelle Waxy Cap or Goblet Wax Cap

NEARBY TREES: Conifer, predominately Silver Fir and Hemlock, with scattered Alder and Vine Maple.

SUBSTRATE: Wood Pieces, Leaf Litter, Dense Humus Soil, Needle Duff, Moss. Soil was slightly damp.

HABIT: In clusters of 2-4…found in two separate locations on the edge of what is normally a wetland area….lots of damp mud, but no standing water.

ODOR: Pleasant
TASTE: Indistinct

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION (Note: all parts of this mushroom are very fragile):

CAP: Dry, very finely fibrillose; pale orange, 3/8 – 1 3/8 inches across; broadly convex… on older specimens the center is either umbilicate or depressed, with an in-rolled and finely scalloped margin; edge of scalloping dries to a medium brown; there also appear to be thin lines radiating from the center to the margin…the end of the line corresponds to the indent of the scalloped area.

GILLS: Decurrent; nearly distant; thick at the base with sharp edges; pale yellow; short-gills present between each full-length gill and correspond with the indent of the scalloped area.

STIPE: 1-4 inches long; 2-4 mm thick; wider at the top, tapering to a narrow base; dry, bald; pale yellow at the top, becoming a light reddish orange, with a yellowish base. No coloring where the Stipe has been cut. The large area of the Stipe’s top is hollow in a curved-sided, isosceles triangular shape, with the triangle base corresponding with the Cap’s central indentation. The remainder of the Stipe is also hollow, but is very narrow, ~1mm wide.

SPORES: Ostensibly white, but unknown at this time.

MYCELIA: White, very dense, directly below the forest duff. Appears to run very shallow in the dark humus substrate, ~ 1/8”

results.notes:
Lignícolas; gregarios; micelio blanquecino; píleo (1,5cm) carnoso-fibroso, vinotinto, acampanulado, surcado-estriado a lo largo del píleo, contexto sumamente delgado, sin olor; margen recto, borde con ondas regulares que corresponden a las láminas (crenado?; como en Marasmius rotula); himenio blanquecino-rosa, translúcido, láminas libres, rosa-blanquecinas, muy separadas, estrechas, de borde liso; estípite (6cm) filiforme, rígido, marrón oscuro, brillante, liso.

Descripción usada:

“Pileus 2-5 m m broad when young, 7-12 mm when old, campanulate or obtusely conical, depressed at centre, with denticulate margin, sulcate-striate, dark violaceous. Lamellae distant, L = ca. 13-15, 1 = 0 (-l), adnate, narrow (1-2 mm ), horizontal to slightly ventricose, white-violaceous, with concolorous entire edge. Stipe 30-40 × 0.5-0.6 mm, very thin, filiform, fistulose, ± dark violaceous, with distinct whitish basal tomentum. Context membranaceous, whitish. Spore print whitish to ochraceous.”

results.notes:
ID help is much appreciated! Growing at the disturbed edge of a dense mixed hardwood/coniferous forest in NW Georgia (Gordon County), US. August 19, 2018.

Reddish brown-capped, yellow-pored mushrooms growing in clusters in soil and on exposed tree roots. Neon yellow mycelium. Also bright yellow at base of stipes (when sliced in two). Flesh below cap is pale cream/yellow. Cap, flesh, and pores DNS.

Odor/Cap flavor: VERY pleasant. Sweet and nutty.

Chemical analysis:
Iron salts: Negative on all surfaces.
KOH: Flashes yellow, resolves to black/deep purple on cap. Orange/brown on flesh. Orange on pore surface.
Ammonia: Flashes bright green/blue and resolves to black/purple on cap. Flashes green/blue on flesh and resolves to pinkish brown on flesh. Yellow-olive on pore surface.

DNA sequencing results and discussion (posted 30-May-19):
Results:
> Originally, the LSU locus was requested so that it could be compared to sequences in the wonderful 2016 Retiboletus study by Zeng et al. (The Genus Retiboletus in China). However, LSU inexplicably failed, which may not necessarily be a problem with this sample, but a rather a technical issue (i.e., reagents). Fortunately, an ITS sequence was obtained from this collection.
> The derived clean and contiguous full-length nrITS sequence is only 474 bps long. There are a few other examples of short ITS in Boletaceae, but typically this locus is well over 500 base pairs. There are no ambiguous sites, it’s a single haplotype.
> A BLASTn search of the sequence returned two high-value hits: “Retiboletus ornatipes voucher FLAS-F-60544” (MH281848) from Florida and “Retiboletus ornatipes strain JJB01 (TENN)” (MF686543) from Tennessee, both at 473/474 = 99.8% similarity. The 392 nd character is a “C” in this sequence, an “N” (any base) in the FL sequence, and a “T” in the TN sequence. Undoubtedly, the three collections are conspecific, but what species do they represent?
Discussion:
Retiboletus ornatipes, originally described by Peck from NY state as a nom. nov. for “Boletus retipes B. & C.” sensu Peck,1 allegedly occurs all the way down to the Gulf states. Berkeley & Curtis’ R. retipes,2 originating from NC, is understood to be a southern species with an unknown range of distribution in the northern direction. Naturally, the two are presumed to overlap. However, it’s unclear – in the absence of genetic data – if the holotypes of these two taxa represent a single taxon or two discrete entities.
The aforementioned Retiboletus study by Zheng et al. reveals that there exist at least three ornatipes -like taxa in North and Central America. The phylogenetic species the paper calls “ornatipes” is distributed from New England south to NC, but it’s likely a predominantly northeastern taxon presumed to be Peck’s ornatipes. “Retipes” consists of two genetically distinct entities represented by collections from VA, NC, and Costa Rica. Unfortunately, none of these collections have been sampled for ITS.
In all likelihood, MO328625 is R. ornatipes sensu Peck/Zheng et al., but LSU is needed here for a confirmation.
Reference:
1 E.E. Both, The Boletes of North America: a Compendium, p. 214
2 E.E. Both, The Boletes of North America: a Compendium, p. 263

results.notes:
A single fruiting body growing at the base of an old oak. The white material on the pores is not mold, for it was no longer present when I handled this mushroom just prior to drying it.

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion:
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence consisting of the first 984 bps was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this material. There are no ambiguous characters.
A BLASTn search of a 862 bp sequence fragment (the region between ITS6R and LR5 primers) revealed that the top 8 hits are accessions of Tengioboletus spp. from Asia, with similarities in the 98.8-99.3% range and the query cover of 92-100%. The similarity of the hits directly below drops to 95%.
A phylogram consisting of representative nrLSU accessions from genera clading in the subfamily Boletoideae from this hit list was built in GenBank and uploaded to this post. The monophyly of Boletoideae is maintained in this cladogram. B. auripes/MO328940 nests within Tengioboletus.
> A clean and contiguous TEF-1-alpha sequence of 955 bps was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this material. The sequence read starts from the first character following the EF1-983F primer (edited out) and ends in the tef1R primer. Since EF1-983F is 23 bp long, the overall length of the region between and including it and EF1-1567R is 609 base pairs. There are no ambiguous characters in the “full-length” sequence.
A BLASTn search of the first 586 bp (the most commonly sequenced region of TEF-1) revealed that the top 6 hits are accessions of Tengioboletus spp. from Asia, with similarities in the 94.4-96.8% range and the query cover of 100% (5 hits) and 77% (1 hit). The similarity of the hits directly below drops to 88%.
A phylogram consisting of representative TEF-1 accession from genera clading in the subfamily Boletoideae from this hit list was built in GenBank and uploaded to this post. The monophyly of Boletoideae is maintained in this cladogram. B. auripes/MO328940 nests within Tengioboletus.
> Boletus auripes Peck is a readily recognized and morphologically unique member of the Boletaceae. It’s morphological gestalt is so distinct from all the other NA boletes that it’s difficult to confuse it with anything else; only Retiboletus ornatipes and R. retipes superficially resemble it when the cap of auripes is yellow. Those who collected young auripes could have noticed how the immature pore surface is covered by a thin layer of whitish or cream material. The membrane is actually made up of specialized cheiocystidia.1 The cheiocystidia covering is a “trademark” of the porcini mushrooms (Boletus s. str.) – all of them have it. Outside of the porcini s. lat. clade, this morphological phenomenon is rare in the Boletaceae and is probably of homoplastic origin. While B. auripes is not a porcini, the trait could still be symplesiomorphic, as there are indications that B. auripes and Boletus s. str. belong in the same subfamily.2
> Peck’s type of auripes is from Port Jefferson, NY, but the species is widely distributed in eastern North America. According to Mushroom Observer records, it’s been mostly collected along the eastern seaboard: CT, NY, PA, NJ, MD, VA, WV, NC, SC, GA and AL; however, a few isolated records exist from the heart of the country: IN, MO and perhaps AR.
> B. auripes has not been included in any of seminal phylogenetic Boletaceae studies of the last decade, but it would be fair to say that many other notable NA boletes have not escaped this fate. In GenBank, auripes is represented only by three ITS and a single LSU accessions. While ITS is of no value for making intrageneric phylogenetic inferences, it’s the latter locus that allowed me to propose Tengioboletus auripes comb. prov. on MO two years ago.
Alignment of my LSU sequence with GenBank’s KC184477 shows the 619 overlay a 100% match.
As has already been state above, B. auripes appears to be a bona fide member of Tengioboletus, a small genus currently comprised of three described taxa from southeast Asia. Te. reticulatus and Te. glutinosus were described by Wu et al. in 2016.2 Te. fujianensis was described as new to science in 2018.3
References:
1 http://www.czechmycology.org/cmo/CM66205.pdf
2 https://www.researchgate.net/...
3 https://www.researchgate.net/...China

results.notes:
Clearing in oak woods.

Stipe (as pictured) 8 inches long, including portion extracted from soil. Soil very rocky; could not pry some large rocks loose. It is possible that a basal root has been left behind. About an inch down into the soil the upper rim of the volva appeared. Although the volva did not hold together as I pried the mushroom out of the ground, I believe most of the vovla had been dug out of the ground. The photo showing the mushroom laid out along my arm also shows two pieces of membranous volva, one stuck to a leaf. The photo showing the hole in the ground (over 2 inches deep) appears to also show a white stub of embedded material.

Upper stipe densely floccose with coating breaking apart into jagged segments.

Cap with dark hard-fleshed disc forming a low umbo.

Spores mainly subglobose, a few each broadly ellipsoid or globose ~9-13 × 8-12.

results.notes:
This is the type with dark disc that otherwise resembles A. rooseveltensis. Same type habitat as rooseveltensis (from my property), mowed lawn near shagbark hickory. Other trees seem not not be candidates for symbiosis (ash, maple, walnut). This exact spot has produced other examples that appear to variously fit the rooseveltensis concept (as currently understood), obs 324325, obs 282801, obs 279627 (A1, A2), obs 209315 . Upon inspection of these older observations, it appears that all of the “rooseveltensis” collected from this spot (on lawn 30-40 feet east of my house) has the dark disc. The spot 40 feet to the northwest of my house has consistently produced more-or-less gray monocolor material sequenced and thus identified as rooseveltensis, as well as ones with the dark disc.

One fruit body representing this observation is preserved (although this particular material was limp and fairly waterlogged. Another similar fruit body collected from the other spot will be submitted to NAMP, obs 328969.
results.location_name: Property at 239 Golf Course Rd., Hunlock Twp., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
On lawn bordering woods with large shagbark hickory, large white pine, and several small oaks. The oaks are far enough away that I think it’s unlikely any of them are associated with this mushroom.

Rain had just fallen, which is why the cap is wet and there are tiny beads of water on the stipe surface. Ground was very moist, apparently causing this mushroom to be fairly fragile. It broke apart as I attempted to extract it form the soil. Basal volva (detached) will be preserved and included with the rest of the dehydrated material.

Over the years, many similar mushrooms have been collected for this area (~30 square yard area part of which is sloped and part of which is level). A damp line of natural underground drainage runs through this area. The mushroom featured in this observation was collected from the level area. Specimens with the dark disc (like this one) as well as ones with more-or-less monocolor gray caps have often been collected from this same 30 sq yd area. Previously observed/posted (and also included in NAMP) is the observation obs 321879 , which features a monocolor cap, and which was found in the same 30 sq yd area as this present observation.

Found during same day in very similar habitat (but on other side of my house) is obs 328968.

The point here is to try to expand our understanding of the provisional species Amanita rooseveltensis. My understanding is that this species concept is based upon collections of the monocolor types. Partly because both monocolor types and dark-disc ones are found in the same small area of my property, I think these may all represent the same taxon, A. rooseveltensis. My NAMP submissions of material representing both color schemes is meant to test this hypothesis.

The one seen in this observation has a particularly dark disc. Possible contributing factors… cap is unexpanded, weather is rainy. Or, the mushroom seen in this observation may represent a dark-disc rooseveltensis imitator (not actually rooseveltensis).

Both monocolor and dark-disc types collected on my property have consistently similar spore dimensions, mainly broadly ellipsoid 8-12 × 7-9.

results.notes:
These two monocolor specimens found on upper part of slope close to wood border where small oaks are present. Mature shagbark hickory and mature white pine ~25 feet away.

The monocolor type found in this spot partially constitutes the basis for the rooseveltensis concept (as currently understood). Each of the two specimens seen here features a low umbo.

Photos labeled A or B (different specimens). Before the solar array was installed in 2013, the previously open south-facing ridge was the area where most of these were found. After the array was installed, the mushrooms (perhaps two distinct taxa) began to appear on the slope just to west of the array as well as on a nearby level area of lawn. Lately, the appearance of the mushrooms near the NW and SW edge of the array has resumed.

notes_fields.Substrate: Growing on the pore surface of a polypore
notes_fields.Macroscopic_Features: Crust fungus is resupinate, effused, and thin with a smooth to grandinoid hymenophore, spreading over the pore surface of a conk; the margin is indeterminate, thin, and fimbriate; when fresh the specimen is somewhat ceraceous or pruinose.
notes_fields.Microscopic_Features:
Spores curved, narrowly cylindrical (cylindrical to allantoid); length (4.9) 5.2-6.0 (6.3) x width (1.5) 1.8-2.2 (2.4) µm, Q (2.3) 2.5-3.1 (4.1); 37 measured
Basidia terminal, with 4 sterigmata and a basal clamp, subcylindrical to utriform or constricted; length (14.5) 16.6-24.2 (25.7), largest width (3.9) 4.0-4.6 (4.8), smallest width (2.5) 2.6-3.5 (3.7), ratio of length to largest width (3.6) 3.7-5.8 (6.2); sterigmata length (2.1) 2.2-3.2 (3.4); 8 basidia measured
Sterile structures not present

results.notes:
Reported as growing on various shrub species, but I can’t find any reports of this crust growing on other fungi. The question remains whether Galzinia incrustans is acquiring nutrition from the conk or if it is just using it as a prop to better release spores.

Pictures featured on JGI sequence portal for Galzinia incrustans: https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Galinc1/Galinc1.home.html
